rounds.response:
Analysis of the position after 1…Qxg5:  
Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.  
**[resign]**

[White] Analysis of the position after 1…Qxg5:  
Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.  
**[resign]**

I therefore resign by the customary rule: when there is no legal move that avoids mate, resignation is the only proper termination.  

[resign]

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

[White] Analysis of the position after 1…Qxg5:  
Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

[White] Analysis of the position after 1…Qxg5:  
Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

rounds.response:
[GAME] I am compelled to recognize the inevitable: Black's passed pawn is unstoppable, his rooks dominate the whole back rank, and my king will be hunted down on the light squares. Facing the accelerating advance of a free pawn coupled with harmonious rook deployment, any further shuffle is mere formalism.

White is in Zugzwang: every move I make either blocks my own pieces or fails to stop the pawn, while all Black has to do is keep rolling it forward.

I therefore resign by the book.

**[resign]**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

I therefore resign by the book.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.

[White] Analysis of the position after 1…Qxg5:  
Black has just captured my bishop with …Qxg5, giving him a strong queen on the only open file and doubled rooks on the g-file ready to crash through.  
White is up the exchange but the pawn skeleton is rammed and there are safe checks: …Qg4+/Qg3+ followed by …Rg2+ are coming. The h-pawn is about to drop, and then pressure on g2 will be unbearable.

**Critical computer line**: 2 Kf2 Qg4 3 Kg1 Qg3 4 h3 Rg2+ 5 Kh1 Rcg8 and mate is forced in at most five more moves.

With perfect play the position is **won for Black** because he controls the only open file, has a rampant queen, and White has no counterplay.

No useful legal move prevents …Qg4+, nor does any king shuffle. Any rook move further opens the king to mate on the g-file; every king shuffle allows …Qg4/Qg3; every pawn advance merely drops the h-pawn instantly.

Final verdict: **White has a lost position.**

I therefore resign conventionally.
